conclusion: Analyze the motion of the charged particle in the magnetic field and use the given conditions to find the magnetic induction B.
The particle is injected with velocity v0 at an angle of 45° to MN.
The velocity components are v0x = v0 cos 45° = v0/√2 and v0y = v0 sin 45° = v0/√2.
The particle moves in a circular path due to the magnetic field.
The radius R of the circular path is given by R = mv/qB, where v is the speed of the particle.
The horizontal component of the velocity reverses direction while the vertical component remains unchanged after collision with the insulating plate.
After the collision, the particle continues to move in a circular path in the opposite direction.
The particle travels a distance of 2d horizontally before colliding with the insulating plate.
The time taken to travel this distance is t = 2d/v0x = 2d/(v0/√2) = 2d√2/v0.
The period T of the circular motion is T = 2πR/v.
Since the particle completes half a circle before colliding with the plate, the time taken is T/2 = πR/v.
Equate the time taken to travel 2d horizontally to the time taken to complete half a circle: 2d√2/v0 = πR/v.
Since v = v0 (speed remains constant), we have: 2d√2/v0 = πR/v0.
Using the relation R = mv/qB, substitute R and v = v0: 2d√2/π = mv0/qB.
The magnitude of the magnetic induction B is: B = mv0π/(2d√2q).
